p: All modeling was conducted in R ver. 3.1.2 (R Core Team, 2013) using packages “ape” (Paradis, Claude, & Strimmer, 2004) and “MCMCglmm” (Hadfield, 2010); see Appendix S1 for R code. Fixed factors to examine the influence on VO 2 included: test temperature (5, 15, 25°C), acclimation temperature (14 and 22°C), and range size (latitudinal extent, as well as species grouped as wide vs. narrow‐ranging). To assign species as wide or narrow‐ranging, a natural break was found between species with latitudinal extents greater than or less than five degrees of latitude. Sex and genus were also included as covariates in the model. As Desmognathus salamanders are often associated with streams and seeps, they could be better buffered from temperature extremes than more terrestrial Plethodon salamanders. This could have a potential influence on salamander physiological tolerances and SMR. The covariate “genus” therefore divides Plethodon from Desmognathus to help to control for differences in thermal habitat associated with each group.
